terms.definition: The CDISC version of the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive (ADAS-Cog CDISC Version) containing 15 summary-level tests. This version is based on combining the total pool of ADAS-Cog tests that were observed during a review of multiple case report forms administered in clinical trials of Alzheimer's disease, as well as the CRF administered in the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) observational study. (Modified from Mohs RC, Rosen WG, Davis KL. The Alzheimer's disease assessment scale: an instrument for assessing treatment efficacy. Psychopharmacol Bull 1983;19(3):448-450. Rosen WG, Mohs RC, Davis KL. A new rating scale for Alzheimer's disease. Am J Psychiatry 1984;141(11):1356-1364. Mohs RC, Knopman D, Petersen RC et al. Development of cognitive instruments for use in clinical trials of antidementia drugs: additions to the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale that broaden its scope. The Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study. Alzheimer Dis Assoc Disord 1997;11 Suppl 2:S13-S21. Wouters H, van Gool WA, Schmand B, Lindeboom R. Revising the ADAS-cog for a more accurate assessment of cognitive impairment. Alzheimer Dis Assoc Disord 2008;22(3):236-244.).
terms.preferredTerm: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive CDISC Version Questionnaire

codelists.definition: The Neuropsychiatric Inventory test name.
codelists.name: Neuropsychiatric Inventory Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire NPI Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have beliefs that you know are not true? (for example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her)? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home? I'm not asking about mere suspiciousness; I am interested if the patient is convinced that these things are happening to him/her.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Have Beliefs That You Know are Not True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that he/she is in danger - that others are planning to hurt him/her?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that others are stealing from him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Others are Stealing From Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse is having an affair?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse is Having an Affair

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Unwelcome Guests are Living in His/Her House

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse or Others Are Not Who They Claim To Be

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her house is not his/her home?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her House Is Not His/Her Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Family Members Plan to Abandon Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? (Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?)
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Television or Magazine Figures Are Actually Present In the Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Unusual Things That I Haven't Asked About

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the delusions.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the delusions.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have hallucinations such as seeing false visions or hearing false voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear or experience things that are not present? By this question we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who has died is still alive; rather we are asking if the patient actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Such as Seeing False Visions or Hearing False Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe hearing voices or act as if he/she hears voices?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Hearing Voices or Act as if He/She Hears Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to people who are not there?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to People Who Are Not There

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others (people, animals, lights, etc.)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Seeing Things Not Seen by Others
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others
synonyms: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient report smelling odors not smelled by others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Report Smelling Odors Not Smelled by Others
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell
synonyms: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe feeling things on his/her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Feeling Things on His/Her Skin

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe tastes that are without any known cause?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Tastes That Are Without Any Known Cause

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Any Other Unusual Sensory Experiences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the hallucinations.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the hallucinations.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods when he/she refuses to cooperate or won't let people help him/her? Is he/she hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods When He/She Refuses to Cooperate

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get upset with those trying to care for him/her or resist activities such as bathing or changing clothes?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Upset with Those Trying to Care for Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient stubborn, having to have things his/her way?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other behaviors that make him/her hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Behaviors That Make Him/Her Hard to Handle

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient shout or curse angrily?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient slam doors, kick furniture, throw things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Slam doors, Kick Furniture, Throw Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient attempt to hurt or hit others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Attempt to Hurt or Hit Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other aggressive or agitated behaviors?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Aggressive or Agitated Behaviors

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the agitation/aggression.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the agitation/aggression.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem sad or depressed? Does he/she say that he/she feels sad or depressed?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of tearfulness or sobbing that seem to indicate sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Tearfulness or Sobbing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say, or act as if he/she is sad or in low spirits?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say, or Act as if He/She is Sad or in Low Spirits
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits
synonyms: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient put him/herself down or say that he/she feels like a failure?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Put Him/Herself Down or Say That He/She Feels Like a Failure

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is a bad person or deserves to be punished?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is a Bad Person

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem very discouraged or say that he/she has no future?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say he/she is a burden to the family or that the family would be better off without him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say He/She is a Burden to the Family

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient express a wish for death or talk about killing himself/herself?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Express a Wish for Death

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of depression or sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Depression or Sadness

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the depression/dysphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the depression/dysphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the patient afraid to be apart from you?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Very Nervous, Worried, or Frightened for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is worried about planned events?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is Worried About Planned Events

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Feeling Shaky, Unable to Relax, or Feeling Excessively Tense

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Shortness of Breath, Gasping, or Sighing for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient complain of butterflies in his/her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness? (Symptoms not explained by ill health).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Complain of Butterflies, Racing or Pounding Heart

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meeting with friends, or being in crowds?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Avoid Certain Places or Situations That Make Him/Her More Nervous

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient become nervous and upset when separated from you (or his/her caregiver)? (Does he/she cling to you to keep from being separated?).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Become Nervous and Upset When Separated From You

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of anxiety?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Anxiety

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the anxiety.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the anxiety.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem too cheerful or too happy for no reason? I don't mean the normal happiness that comes from seeing friends, receiving presents, or spending time with family members. I am asking if the patient has a persistent and abnormally good mood or finds humor where others do not.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Too Cheerful or Too Happy for No Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient appear to feel good or to be too happy, different from his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appear to Feel Good or to Be Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient find humor and laugh at things that others do not find funny?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Fine Humor and Laugh at Things That Others Do Not Find Funny
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Humor Others Do Not Find Funny
synonyms: NPI1-Humor Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem to have a childish sense of humor with a tendency to giggle or laugh inappropriately (such as when something unfortunate happens to others)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem to Have a Childish Sense of Humor

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient tell jokes or make remarks that are not funny to others but seem funny to him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Tell Jokes or Make Remarks That are Not Funny to Others
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Jokes Others Do Not Find Funny
synonyms: NPI1-Jokes Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does he/she play childish pranks such as pinching or playing "keep away" for the fun of it?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient "talk big" or claim to have more abilities or wealth than is true?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Big or Claim to Have More Abilities or Wealth Than is True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of feeling too good or being too happy?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Feeling Too Good or Being Too Happy
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Other Signs of Feeling Too Happy
synonyms: NPI1-Other Signs of Feeling Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the elation/euphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the elation/euphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in the world around him/her? Has he/she lost interest in doing things or does he/she lack motivation for starting new activities? Is he/she more difficult to engage in conversation or in doing chores? Is the patient apathetic or indifferent?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in the World Around Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less spontaneous and less active than usual?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Less Spontaneous and Less Active Than Usual

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less likely to initiate a conversation?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Likely Initiate to Initiate a Conversation

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less affectionate or lacking in emotions when compared to his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Affectionate or Lacking in Emotions

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient contribute less to household chores?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Contribute Less to Household Chores

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less interested in the activities and plans of others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Interested in the Activities and Plans of Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in friends and family members?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in Friends and Family Members

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less enthusiastic about his/her usual interests?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Enthusiastic About His/Her Usual Interests

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs That He/She Doesn't Care About Doing New Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the apathy/indifference.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the apathy/indifference.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem to act impulsively without thinking? Does he/she do or say things that are not usually done or said in public? Does he/she do things that are embarrassing to you or others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem to Act Impulsively Without Thinking

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient act impulsively without appearing to consider the consequences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Act Impulsively without Appearing to Consider the Consequences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to total strangers as if he/she knew them?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to Total Strangers as if He/She Knew Them

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say things to people that are insensitive or hurt their feelings?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say Things to People that are Insensitive

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say crude things or make sexual remarks that he/she would not usually have said?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say Crude Things or Make Sexual Remarks

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk openly about very personal or private matters not usually discussed in public?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Openly About Very Personal or Private Matters

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient take liberties or touch or hug others in a way that is out of character for him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Take Liberties or Touch or Hug Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of loss of control of his/her impulses?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Loss of Control of His/Her Impulses

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the disinhibition.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the disinhibition.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get irritated and easily disturbed? Are his/her moods very changeable? Is he/she abnormally impatient? We do not mean frustration over memory loss or inability to perform usual tasks; we are interested to know if the patient has abnormal irritability, impatience, or rapid emotional changes different from his/her usual self.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Irritated and Easily Disturbed

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have a bad temper, flying "off the handle" easily over little things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Bad Temper, Flying 'Off the Handle' Easily Over Little Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rapidly change moods from one to another, being fine one minute and angry the next?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rapidly Change Moods From One to Another

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have sudden flashes of anger?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient impatient, having trouble coping with delays or waiting for planned activities?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Impatient, Having Trouble Coping with Delays

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient cranky and irritable?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient argumentative and difficult to get along with?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Argumentative and Difficult to Get Along With

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of irritability?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Irritability

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the irritability/lability.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the irritability/lability.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient pace, do things over and over such as opening closets or drawers, or repeatedly pick at things or wind string or threads?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Pace, Do Things Over and Over, Repeatedly Pick at Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient pace around the house without apparent purpose?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Pace Around the House Without Apparent Purpose

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rummage around opening and unpacking drawers or closets?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rummage Around Opening and Unpacking Drawers or Closets

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient repeatedly put on and take off clothing?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Repeatedly Put On and Take Off Clothing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have repetitive activities or "habits" that he/she performs over and over?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient engage in repetitive activities such as handling buttons, picking, wrapping string, etc.?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient fidget excessively, seem unable to sit still, or bounce his/her feet or tap his/her fingers a lot?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Fidget Excessively, Seem Unable to Sit Still

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient do any other activities over and over?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Do Any Other Activities Over and Over

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the aberrant motor behavior.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the aberrant motor behavior.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have difficulty sleeping (do not count as present if the patient simply gets up once or twice per night to go the bathroom and falls back asleep immediately)? Is he/she up at night? Does he/she wander at night, get dressed, or disturb your sleep?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have difficulty falling asleep?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get up during the night (do not count if the patient gets up once or twice per night only to go to the bathroom and falls back asleep immediately)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Up During the Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wander, pace or get involved in inappropriate activities at night?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wander, Pace or Get Involved in Inappropriate Activities at Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient awaken you during the night?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Awaken You During the Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wake up at night, dress, and plan to go out thinking that it is morning and time to start the day?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wake Up at Night, Dress, and Plan to Go Out
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Wake at Night and Think Morning
synonyms: NPI1-Wake at Night and Think Morning

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient awaken too early in the morning (earlier than was his/her habit)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Awaken Too Early in Morning

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient sleep excessively during the day?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep Excessively During the Day

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other nighttime behaviors that bother you that we haven't talked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Nighttime Behaviors That Bother You

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had any change in appetite, weight, or eating habits (count as NA if the patient is incapacitated and has to be fed)? Has there been any change in the type of food he/she prefers?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Change in Appetite, Weight, or Eating Habits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a loss of appetite?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had an increase in appetite?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a loss of weight?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she gained weight?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a change in eating behavior such as putting too much food in his/her mouth at once?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a change in the kind of food he/she likes such as eating too many sweets or other specific types of food?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Change in Kind of Food He/She Likes

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she developed eating behaviors such as eating exactly the same types of food each day or eating the food in exactly the same order?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Developed Eating Behaviors Such as Eating Exactly the Same Types of Food

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Have there been any other changes in appetite or eating that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Changes in Appetite or Eating

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the changes in eating habits or appetite.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the changes in eating habits or appetite.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Distress

codelists.definition: The Neuropsychiatric Inventory test code.
codelists.name: Neuropsychiatric Inventory Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire NPI Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have beliefs that you know are not true? (for example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her)? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home? I'm not asking about mere suspiciousness; I am interested if the patient is convinced that these things are happening to him/her.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Have Beliefs That You Know are Not True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that he/she is in danger - that others are planning to hurt him/her?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that others are stealing from him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Others are Stealing From Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse is having an affair?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse is Having an Affair

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Unwelcome Guests are Living in His/Her House

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse or Others Are Not Who They Claim To Be

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her house is not his/her home?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her House Is Not His/Her Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Family Members Plan to Abandon Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? (Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?)
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Television or Magazine Figures Are Actually Present In the Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Unusual Things That I Haven't Asked About

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the delusions.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the delusions.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have hallucinations such as seeing false visions or hearing false voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear or experience things that are not present? By this question we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who has died is still alive; rather we are asking if the patient actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Such as Seeing False Visions or Hearing False Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe hearing voices or act as if he/she hears voices?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Hearing Voices or Act as if He/She Hears Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to people who are not there?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to People Who Are Not There

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others (people, animals, lights, etc.)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Seeing Things Not Seen by Others
synonyms: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient report smelling odors not smelled by others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Report Smelling Odors Not Smelled by Others
synonyms: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe feeling things on his/her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Feeling Things on His/Her Skin

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe tastes that are without any known cause?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Tastes That Are Without Any Known Cause

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Any Other Unusual Sensory Experiences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the hallucinations.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the hallucinations.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods when he/she refuses to cooperate or won't let people help him/her? Is he/she hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods When He/She Refuses to Cooperate

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get upset with those trying to care for him/her or resist activities such as bathing or changing clothes?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Upset with Those Trying to Care for Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient stubborn, having to have things his/her way?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other behaviors that make him/her hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Behaviors That Make Him/Her Hard to Handle

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient shout or curse angrily?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient slam doors, kick furniture, throw things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Slam doors, Kick Furniture, Throw Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient attempt to hurt or hit others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Attempt to Hurt or Hit Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other aggressive or agitated behaviors?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Aggressive or Agitated Behaviors

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the agitation/aggression.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the agitation/aggression.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem sad or depressed? Does he/she say that he/she feels sad or depressed?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of tearfulness or sobbing that seem to indicate sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Tearfulness or Sobbing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say, or act as if he/she is sad or in low spirits?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say, or Act as if He/She is Sad or in Low Spirits
synonyms: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient put him/herself down or say that he/she feels like a failure?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Put Him/Herself Down or Say That He/She Feels Like a Failure

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is a bad person or deserves to be punished?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is a Bad Person

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem very discouraged or say that he/she has no future?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say he/she is a burden to the family or that the family would be better off without him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say He/She is a Burden to the Family

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient express a wish for death or talk about killing himself/herself?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Express a Wish for Death

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of depression or sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Depression or Sadness

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the depression/dysphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the depression/dysphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the patient afraid to be apart from you?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Very Nervous, Worried, or Frightened for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is worried about planned events?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is Worried About Planned Events

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Feeling Shaky, Unable to Relax, or Feeling Excessively Tense

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Shortness of Breath, Gasping, or Sighing for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient complain of butterflies in his/her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness? (Symptoms not explained by ill health).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Complain of Butterflies, Racing or Pounding Heart

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meeting with friends, or being in crowds?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Avoid Certain Places or Situations That Make Him/Her More Nervous

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient become nervous and upset when separated from you (or his/her caregiver)? (Does he/she cling to you to keep from being separated?).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Become Nervous and Upset When Separated From You

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of anxiety?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Anxiety

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the anxiety.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the anxiety.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem too cheerful or too happy for no reason? I don't mean the normal happiness that comes from seeing friends, receiving presents, or spending time with family members. I am asking if the patient has a persistent and abnormally good mood or finds humor where others do not.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Too Cheerful or Too Happy for No Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient appear to feel good or to be too happy, different from his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appear to Feel Good or to Be Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient find humor and laugh at things that others do not find funny?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Fine Humor and Laugh at Things That Others Do Not Find Funny
synonyms: NPI1-Humor Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem to have a childish sense of humor with a tendency to giggle or laugh inappropriately (such as when something unfortunate happens to others)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem to Have a Childish Sense of Humor

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient tell jokes or make remarks that are not funny to others but seem funny to him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Tell Jokes or Make Remarks That are Not Funny to Others
synonyms: NPI1-Jokes Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does he/she play childish pranks such as pinching or playing "keep away" for the fun of it?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient "talk big" or claim to have more abilities or wealth than is true?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Big or Claim to Have More Abilities or Wealth Than is True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of feeling too good or being too happy?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Feeling Too Good or Being Too Happy
synonyms: NPI1-Other Signs of Feeling Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the elation/euphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the elation/euphoria.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in the world around him/her? Has he/she lost interest in doing things or does he/she lack motivation for starting new activities? Is he/she more difficult to engage in conversation or in doing chores? Is the patient apathetic or indifferent?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in the World Around Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less spontaneous and less active than usual?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Less Spontaneous and Less Active Than Usual

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less likely to initiate a conversation?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Likely Initiate to Initiate a Conversation

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less affectionate or lacking in emotions when compared to his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Affectionate or Lacking in Emotions

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient contribute less to household chores?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Contribute Less to Household Chores

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less interested in the activities and plans of others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Interested in the Activities and Plans of Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in friends and family members?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in Friends and Family Members

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less enthusiastic about his/her usual interests?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Enthusiastic About His/Her Usual Interests

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs That He/She Doesn't Care About Doing New Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the apathy/indifference.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the apathy/indifference.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem to act impulsively without thinking? Does he/she do or say things that are not usually done or said in public? Does he/she do things that are embarrassing to you or others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem to Act Impulsively Without Thinking

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient act impulsively without appearing to consider the consequences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Act Impulsively without Appearing to Consider the Consequences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to total strangers as if he/she knew them?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to Total Strangers as if He/She Knew Them

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say things to people that are insensitive or hurt their feelings?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say Things to People that are Insensitive

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say crude things or make sexual remarks that he/she would not usually have said?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say Crude Things or Make Sexual Remarks

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk openly about very personal or private matters not usually discussed in public?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Openly About Very Personal or Private Matters

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient take liberties or touch or hug others in a way that is out of character for him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Take Liberties or Touch or Hug Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of loss of control of his/her impulses?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Loss of Control of His/Her Impulses

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the disinhibition.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the disinhibition.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get irritated and easily disturbed? Are his/her moods very changeable? Is he/she abnormally impatient? We do not mean frustration over memory loss or inability to perform usual tasks; we are interested to know if the patient has abnormal irritability, impatience, or rapid emotional changes different from his/her usual self.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Irritated and Easily Disturbed

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have a bad temper, flying "off the handle" easily over little things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Bad Temper, Flying 'Off the Handle' Easily Over Little Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rapidly change moods from one to another, being fine one minute and angry the next?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rapidly Change Moods From One to Another

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have sudden flashes of anger?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient impatient, having trouble coping with delays or waiting for planned activities?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Impatient, Having Trouble Coping with Delays

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient cranky and irritable?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient argumentative and difficult to get along with?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Argumentative and Difficult to Get Along With

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of irritability?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Irritability

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the irritability/lability.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the irritability/lability.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient pace, do things over and over such as opening closets or drawers, or repeatedly pick at things or wind string or threads?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Pace, Do Things Over and Over, Repeatedly Pick at Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient pace around the house without apparent purpose?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Pace Around the House Without Apparent Purpose

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rummage around opening and unpacking drawers or closets?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rummage Around Opening and Unpacking Drawers or Closets

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient repeatedly put on and take off clothing?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Repeatedly Put On and Take Off Clothing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have repetitive activities or "habits" that he/she performs over and over?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient engage in repetitive activities such as handling buttons, picking, wrapping string, etc.?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient fidget excessively, seem unable to sit still, or bounce his/her feet or tap his/her fingers a lot?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Fidget Excessively, Seem Unable to Sit Still

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient do any other activities over and over?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Do Any Other Activities Over and Over

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the aberrant motor behavior.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the aberrant motor behavior.
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?

Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have difficulty sleeping (do not count as present if the patient simply gets up once or twice per night to go the bathroom and falls back asleep immediately)? Is he/she up at night? Does he/she wander at night, get dressed, or disturb your sleep?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have difficulty falling asleep?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get up during the night (do not count if the patient gets up once or twice per night only to go to the bathroom and falls back asleep immediately)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Up During the Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wander, pace or get involved in inappropriate activities at night?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wander, Pace or Get Involved in Inappropriate Activities at Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient awaken you during the night?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Awaken You During the Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wake up at night, dress, and plan to go out thinking that it is morning and time to start the day?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wake Up at Night, Dress, and Plan to Go Out
synonyms: NPI1-Wake at Night and Think Morning

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient awaken too early in the morning (earlier than was his/her habit)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Awaken Too Early in Morning

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient sleep excessively during the day?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep Excessively During the Day

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other nighttime behaviors that bother you that we haven't talked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Nighttime Behaviors That Bother You

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had any change in appetite, weight, or eating habits (count as NA if the patient is incapacitated and has to be fed)? Has there been any change in the type of food he/she prefers?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Change in Appetite, Weight, or Eating Habits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a loss of appetite?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had an increase in appetite?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a loss of weight?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she gained weight?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a change in eating behavior such as putting too much food in his/her mouth at once?
Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a change in the kind of food he/she likes such as eating too many sweets or other specific types of food?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Change in Kind of Food He/She Likes

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she developed eating behaviors such as eating exactly the same types of food each day or eating the food in exactly the same order?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Developed Eating Behaviors Such as Eating Exactly the Same Types of Food

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Have there been any other changes in appetite or eating that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Changes in Appetite or Eating

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the changes in eating habits or appetite.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the changes in eating habits or appetite.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appetite and Eating Disorders Distress

codelists.definition: The Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale test name.
codelists.name: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire PDQUALIF Test Name Terminology
synonyms: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Test Name

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Changing position causes me to become lightheaded (lying to standing, or sitting to standing).
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - When walking, I have trouble keeping my balance.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - When eating or drinking fluids, I have difficulty swallowing.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms affect my ability to communicate with people.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - The need to go to the bathroom keeps me up at night.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms affect my ability to show affection in intimate or sexual ways.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I have aching/burning/coldness/numbness in my hand/feet.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Neuropathy in Hands or Feet

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I have difficulty with bladder control (frequency, urgency, inability).
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Constipation is a problem.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to have trouble falling asleep, or waking early.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Trouble with Sleep Initiation or Waking Early

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I have trouble staying asleep.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms make it hard to maintain a positive outlook.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to feel like a burden to other people.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have affected my social life.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I worry about what the future has in store.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Asking others for help is difficult for me.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Difficulty in Asking for Help

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Maintaining my independence is important to me.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - It has been difficult to adjust to the changes which have taken place in my body.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Difficulty in Adjusting to Change

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have not affected my social life.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Travel remains an important part of my leisure activities.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have affected my family role and responsibility.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to stay away from social gatherings.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My spouse/children/friends' view of me has changed because of my illness.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I feel I am less sexually desirable because of my illness.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, in my personal hygiene (bathing, hair care, make up, shaving or toileting), I have been independent.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Independent Hygiene in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, in food preparation or eating I am independent.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Independent Food Preparation in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, written or spoken communication is a problem for me.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Problem with Communication in the Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, fatigue makes participation in activities, household chores, shopping or yard work a problem for me.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, my Parkinson's symptoms interfere with my ability to do my usual share in the home.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - House Work in Past 7 Days
terms.submissionValue: PDQ01-Usual Share of Work in Home
synonyms: PDQ01-Usual Share of Work in Home

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, my nighttime symptoms keep me from sleeping with my spouse/partner.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Sleep with Partner in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, my Parkinson's symptoms have interfered with my driving ability.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, my illness has caused a financial strain for me and my family.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Financial Strain in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Compared to 6 months ago, my Parkinson's symptoms are.

codelists.definition: The Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale test code.
codelists.name: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire PDQUALIF Test Code Terminology
synonyms: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Test Code

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Changing position causes me to become lightheaded (lying to standing, or sitting to standing).
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - When walking, I have trouble keeping my balance.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - When eating or drinking fluids, I have difficulty swallowing.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms affect my ability to communicate with people.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - The need to go to the bathroom keeps me up at night.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms affect my ability to show affection in intimate or sexual ways.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I have aching/burning/coldness/numbness in my hand/feet.

Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Constipation is a problem.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to have trouble falling asleep, or waking early.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Trouble with Sleep Initiation or Waking Early

Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to feel like a burden to other people.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have affected my social life.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I worry about what the future has in store.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Asking others for help is difficult for me.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Difficulty in Asking for Help

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Maintaining my independence is important to me.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - It has been difficult to adjust to the changes which have taken place in my body.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Difficulty in Adjusting to Change

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have not affected my social life.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - Travel remains an important part of my leisure activities.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms have affected my family role and responsibility.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My Parkinson's symptoms cause me to stay away from social gatherings.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - My spouse/children/friends' view of me has changed because of my illness.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - I feel I am less sexually desirable because of my illness.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, in my personal hygiene (bathing, hair care, make up, shaving or toileting), I have been independent.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Independent Hygiene in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, in food preparation or eating I am independent.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Independent Food Preparation in Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, written or spoken communication is a problem for me.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - Problem with Communication in the Past 7 Days

terms.definition: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, fatigue makes participation in activities, household chores, shopping or yard work a problem for me.
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale - In the past 7 days, my Parkinson's symptoms interfere with my ability to do my usual share in the home.
terms.preferredTerm: PDQUALIF - House Work in Past 7 Days
synonyms: PDQ01-Usual Share of Work in Home

codelists.name: Clinical Global Impression Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire CGI Test Name Terminology

terms.definition: Clinical Global Impression - Considering your total clinical experience with this particular population, how mentally ill is the patient at this time?

Clinical Global Impression - Rate total improvement whether or not, in your judgment, it is due entirely to drug treatment. Compared to his condition at admission to the project, how much has he changed?

Clinical Global Impression - Rate this item on the basis of drug effect only. Select the terms which best describe the degrees of therapeutic effect and side effects and record the number in the box where the two items intersect.

codelists.definition: Current Opioid Misuse Measure test name.
codelists.name: Current Opioid Misuse Measure Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire COMM Test Name Terminology
synonyms: Current Opioid Misuse Measure Test Name

terms.definition: Current Opioid Misuse Measure - In the past 30 days, how often have you had trouble with thinking clearly or had memory problems?
terms.preferredTerm: COMM - Trouble Thinking Clearly or Memory Problems

terms.definition: Current Opioid Misuse Measure - In the past 30 days, how often do people complain that you are not completing necessary tasks? (i.e., doing things that need to be done, such as going to class, work or appointments)

Current Opioid Misuse Measure - In the past 30 days, how often have you had to go to someone other than your prescribing physician to get sufficient pain relief from medications? (i.e., another doctor, the Emergency Room, friends, street source)
terms.preferredTerm: COMM - Other Sources for Pain Medication

terms.definition: Current Opioid Misuse Measure - In the past 30 days, how often have you taken your medications differently from how they are prescribed?

terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Deterrents to Most Severe Ideation

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - What sort of reasons did you have for thinking about wanting to die or killing yourself? Was it to end the pain or stop the way you were feeling (in other words you couldn't go on living with this pain or how you were feeling) or was it to get attention, revenge or a reaction from others? Or both?
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Reasons for Most Severe Ideation

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Have you made a suicide attempt? Have you done anything to harm yourself? Have you done anything dangerous where you could have died?
Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Total number of actual attempts.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Number of Actual Suicide Attempts

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Description of actual attempt.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Description of Actual Suicide Attempts

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Has the subject engaged in non-suicidal self-injurious behavior.

Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Has there been a time when you started to do something to try to end your life but someone or something stopped you before you actually did anything?
Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Total number of interrupted attempts.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Number of Interrupted Suicide Attempts

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Description of interrupted attempt.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Description of Interrupted Suicide Attempt

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Has there been a time when you started to do something to try to end your life but you stopped yourself before you actually did anything?
Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Total number of aborted attempts.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Number of Aborted Suicide Attempts

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Description of aborted attempt.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Description of Aborted Suicide Attempt

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Have you taken any steps toward making a suicide attempt or preparing to kill yourself (such as collecting pills, getting a gun, giving valuables away or writing a suicide note)?
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Preparatory Acts or Behaviors Toward Suicide Attempt

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Description of preparatory acts or behaviors.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Description of Preparatory Acts or Behaviors Toward Suicide Attempt

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Suicidal behavior was present during the assessment period?
Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most recent actual attempt date.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Recent Suicide Attempt Date

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most recent actual attempt lethality/medical damage.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Recent Suicide Attempt Damage

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most recent actual attempt potential lethality.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Recent Suicide Attempt Potential

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most lethal actual attempt date.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Lethal Suicide Attempt Date

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most lethal actual attempt lethality/medical damage.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Lethal Suicide Attempt Damage

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Most lethal actual attempt potential lethality.
terms.preferredTerm: C-SSRS Baseline - Most Lethal Suicide Attempt Potential

terms.definition: Columbia-Suicidality Severity Rating Scale Baseline - Initial/first actual attempt date.

codelists.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale test name.
codelists.name: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire AIMS Test Name Terminology
synonyms: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale Test Name

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Muscles of facial expression, e.g., movements of forehead, eyebrows, periorbital area, cheeks. Include frowning, blinking, grimacing of upper face.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Lips and perioral area, e.g., puckering, pouting, smacking.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Jaw, e.g., biting, clenching, chewing, mouth opening, lateral movement.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Tongue. Rate only increase in movement both in and out of mouth, not inability to sustain movement.

Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Extremity Movements, Upper (arms, wrists, hands, fingers). Include movements that are choreic (rapid, objectively purposeless, irregular, spontaneous) or athetoid (slow, irregular, complex, serpentine). Do not include tremor (repetitive, regular, rhythmic movements).
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Extremity Movements, Lower (legs, knees, ankles, toes), e.g., lateral knee movement, foot tapping, heel dropping, foot squirming, inversion and eversion of foot.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Trunk Movements, Neck, shoulders, hips, e.g., rocking, twisting, squirming, pelvic gyrations. Include diaphragmatic movements.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Severity of abnormal movements, based on the highest single score on the above items.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Incapacitation due to abnormal movements.
terms.preferredTerm: AIMS - Incapacitation Due to Abnormal Movements

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Patient's awareness of abnormal movements.
terms.preferredTerm: AIMS - Patient's Awareness of Abnormal Movements

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Dental Status, Current problems with teeth and/or dentures.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Dental Status, Does patient usually wear dentures?

codelists.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale test code.
codelists.name: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire AIMS Test Code Terminology
synonyms: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale Test Code

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Muscles of facial expression, e.g., movements of forehead, eyebrows, periorbital area, cheeks. Include frowning, blinking, grimacing of upper face.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Lips and perioral area, e.g., puckering, pouting, smacking.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Jaw, e.g., biting, clenching, chewing, mouth opening, lateral movement.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Facial and Oral Movements, Tongue. Rate only increase in movement both in and out of mouth, not inability to sustain movement.

Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Extremity Movements, Upper (arms, wrists, hands, fingers). Include movements that are choreic (rapid, objectively purposeless, irregular, spontaneous) or athetoid (slow, irregular, complex, serpentine). Do not include tremor (repetitive, regular, rhythmic movements).
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Extremity Movements, Lower (legs, knees, ankles, toes), e.g., lateral knee movement, foot tapping, heel dropping, foot squirming, inversion and eversion of foot.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Trunk Movements, Neck, shoulders, hips, e.g., rocking, twisting, squirming, pelvic gyrations. Include diaphragmatic movements.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Severity of abnormal movements, based on the highest single score on the above items.
Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Incapacitation due to abnormal movements.
terms.preferredTerm: AIMS - Incapacitation Due to Abnormal Movements

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Global Judgments, Patient's awareness of abnormal movements.
terms.preferredTerm: AIMS - Patient's Awareness of Abnormal Movements

terms.definition: Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale - Dental Status, Current problems with teeth and/or dentures.

codelists.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale test name.
codelists.name: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale Test Name
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire HAMA Test Name Terminology
synonyms: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale Test Name

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Anxious mood: worries, anticipation of the worst, fearful anticipation, irritability.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Tension: feelings of tension, fatigability, startle response, moved to tears easily, trembling, feelings of restlessness, inability to relax.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Fears: of dark, of strangers, of being left alone, of animals, of traffic, of crowds.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Insomnia: difficulty falling asleep, broken sleep, unsatisfying sleep and fatigue on waking, dreams, nightmares, night terrors.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Intellectual: difficulty in concentration, poor memory.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Depressed mood: loss of interest, lack of pleasure in hobbies, depression, early waking, diurnal swing.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Somatic (muscular): pains and aches, twitching, stiffness, myoclonic jerks, grinding of teeth, unsteady voice, increased muscular tone.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Somatic (sensory): tinnitus, blurring of vision, hot and cold flushes, feelings of weakness, pricking sensation.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Cardiovascular symptoms: tachycardia, palpitations, pain in chest, throbbing of vessels, fainting feelings, missing beat.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Respiratory symptoms: pressure or constriction in chest, choking feelings, sighing, dyspnea.

Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Gastrointestinal symptoms: difficulty swallowing, wind abdominal pain, burning sensations, abdominal fullness, nausea, vomiting, borborygmi, looseness of bowels, loss of weight, constipation.

Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Genitourinary symptoms: frequency of micturition, urgency of micturition, amenorrhea, menorrhagia, development of frigidity, premature ejaculation, loss of libido, impotence.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Autonomic symptoms: dry mouth, flushing, pallor, tendency to sweat, giddiness, tension, headache, raising of hair.
Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Behavior at interview: fidgeting, restlessness or pacing, tremor of hands, furrowed brow, strained face, sighing or rapid respiration, facial pallor, swallowing, etc.

terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Activities of Daily Living: Tremor

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Activities of daily living (for both 'on' and 'off'): Sensory complaints related to Parkinsonism.
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Activities of Daily Living: Sensory Complaints Related to Parkinsonism

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Speech.
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Facial expression.
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Tremor at rest (head, upper and lower extremities).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Motor Examination: Tremor at Rest

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Action or postural tremor of hands.
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Motor Examination: Action or Postural Tremor of Hand

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Rigidity (Judged on passive movement of major joints with patient relaxed in sitting position. Cogwheeling to be ignored.).
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Finger taps (Patient taps thumb with index finger in rapid succession.).
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Hand movements (Patient opens and closes hands in rapid succession.).

Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Rapid alternating movements of hands (Pronation-supination movements of hands, vertically and horizontally, with as large an amplitude as possible, both hands simultaneously.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Motor Examination: Rapid Alternating Movements of Hands

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Leg agility (Patient taps heel on the ground in rapid succession picking up entire leg. Amplitude should be at least 3 inches.).
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Arising from chair (Patient attempts to rise from a straightbacked chair, with arms folded across chest.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Motor Examination: Arising from Chair

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Posture.
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Gait.

Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Postural stability (Response to sudden, strong posterior displacement produced by pull on shoulders while patient erect with eyes open and feet slightly apart. Patient is prepared.).

Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Body bradykinesia and hypokinesia (Combining slowness, hesitancy, decreased arm swing, small amplitude, and poverty of movement in general.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Motor Examination: Body Bradykinesia and Hypokinesia

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Dyskinesias, Duration: What proportion of the waking day are dyskinesias present? (Historical information.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Dyskinesias - Duration

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Dyskinesias, Disability: How disabling are the dyskinesias? (Historical information; may be modified by office examination.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Dyskinesias - Disability

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Dyskinesias, Painful dyskinesias: How painful are the dyskinesias?
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Dyskinesias - Painful Dyskinesias

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Dyskinesias, Presence of early morning dystonia (Historical information.).
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Dyskinesias - Presence of Early Morning Dystonia

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Clinical fluctuations, Are 'off' periods predictable?
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Clinical Fluctuations - Off Periods Predictable

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Clinical fluctuations, Are 'off' periods unpredictable?
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Clinical Fluctuations - Off Periods Unpredictable

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Clinical fluctuations, Do 'off' periods come on suddenly, within a few seconds?
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Clinical Fluctuations - Off Periods Sudden

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Clinical fluctuations, What proportion of the waking day is the patient 'off' on average?
terms.preferredTerm: UPDRS - Complications of Therapy: Clinical Fluctuations - Average Off Periods Per Day

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Complications of therapy (in the past week): Other complications, Does the patient have anorexia, nausea, or vomiting?

Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Hand movements (Patient opens and closes hands in rapid succession.).

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Leg agility (Patient taps heel on the ground in rapid succession picking up entire leg. Amplitude should be at least 3 inches.).

terms.definition: Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Posture.
Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale - Motor examination: Gait.
